Title: Show that $\max$ function on $\mathbb R^n$ is convex
Content: I am reading the book Convex Optimization , and I don't understand why a $\max$ function is convex. The function is defined as: $$f(x) = \max(x_1, x_2, \dots, x_n)$$ The book offers the proof shown below: for $0 \leq \theta \leq 1$ $$\begin{aligned} f(\theta x + (1 - \theta)y) &= \max_i \left( \theta x_i + (1 - \theta)y_i \right)\\ & \leq \theta \max_i x_i + (1 - \theta)\max_i y_i\\ &= \theta f(x) + (1 - \theta)f(y) \end{aligned}$$ However, I don't understand why the following inequality holds. $$\max_i (\theta x_i + (1 - \theta)y_i) \leq \theta \max_i x_i + (1 - \theta)\max_i y_i$$
AcceptedAnswer:
Fix $k\in \{1,\ldots,n\}$. We have 
$$\theta x_k + (1-\theta)y_k \leq \theta \max_i x_i + (1-\theta)\max_i y_i$$
because $x_k \leq \max_i x_i$, $y_k \leq \max_i y_i$, $\theta \geq 0$ and $1-\theta \geq 0$. Since the statement above is true for any $k$ we have: $$\max_k [\theta x_k + (1-\theta)y_k]\leq \theta \max_i x_i + (1-\theta)\max_i y_i.$$
